content: Application management solutions with HP OpenView and BEA

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div span span
html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div a span
content: Call to action

tag: html body text table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td h2 span
content: Top developer challenges

tag: html body text table tbody tr td div h3 span
content: Supporting the application in production

tag: html body text table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Developer often called to resolve problems

tag: html body text table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Difficult to recreate problem outside production

tag: html body text table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Need to balance support needs with new development

tag: html body text table tbody tr td div h3 span
content: Addressing application performance issues

tag: html body text table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Detecting problems is often reactive and post-deployment

tag: html body text table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Isolating performance bottlenecks can be difficult

tag: html body text table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Many distributed, complex layers to analyze

tag: html body text table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Developers given vague information on problem

tag: html body text table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Increased time to problem resolution

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: If you are a developer, you probably face a number of development challenges on a daily basis. There's a constant need to keep current on emerging technologies, pressure from your customers to deliver products ahead-of-schedule, and a desire to build robust and scalable architectures.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: Despite understanding the importance of performance to the success of any application, and the attempting to design and architect your application to ensure that it's robust and scalable, performance management is probably more of an after-thought and doesn't become a critical issue until production when the customer experiences a problem.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: If you had a very simple application, it might not be too difficult to diagnose the problem. But, you're probably using Web services, JMS, Servlets, EJBs, and other distributed technologies. When you're given a support request such as, "the application is slow", you're most likely spending countless hours trying to identify and diagnose the performance problem. You won't have enough information to know where to even start, which will make it very difficult to recreate the problem outside of production.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: This leads us to the developer's dilemma. If you want to spend more type playing with new technologies such as grid computing or AOP, or you want to build more functionality, you have to balance that with the requirements to support the application.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td h2 span
content: Resolving performance problems today

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div h3 span
content: Common problem resolution approaches

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Print statements or log files

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Operating system utilities

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Thread dumps

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Simple management tools

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Trial and error!

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div h3 span
content: Key issues in problem resolution today

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Time to resolution is too long

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Developers required to diagnose problems

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Problem may not be code-related

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Often requires multiple diagnostic tools

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div div span span
content: Time spent troubleshooting and fixing application issues...is time not spent on new functionality

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: Consider the "traditional" approach commonly used to deal with performance issues. We are all familiar with the tried-and-true "printf" approach for measuring method call times. This technique can be quite useful, except when you have to correlate individual method times with an end-user experience. Spreadsheets and calculators can be your friend here, but it can be very time consuming.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: You might also be able to leverage a variety of operating system tools to help diagnose the problem. If the production machine is hitting 100% CPU utilization, you might leverage a tool such as glance to analyze the problem. Or, if you're experiencing thread contention or Java memory issues, you might leverage specific JVM tools to identify the bottleneck. Often, these techniques are too bottoms-up, making it difficult, if not impossible, to understand how any single component might impact the end user's experience.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: If you're lucky, you may have had the opportunity to work with some simple management tools. Maybe you're leveraging the WebLogic administration console to get some application server statistics. Or, you might have even toyed with ARM, JMX, or Log4J. Even in these situations, the tools at your disposal often only provide part of the answer, and you are left to piece the puzzle together to resolve the problem.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: Bottom line, many of the current approaches used to diagnose performance problems are often very time-intensive, requiring hours or days to diagnose. Many times, the problem isn't even related to the application. It could be a network issue or a database issue, but you've just wasted three days supporting the application instead of enhancing it.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td h2 span
content: How can HP OpenView Transaction Analyzer (OVTA) help?

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div strong span
content: OVTA - Transaction level monitoring & analysis

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div span
content: Are my transactions flowing smoothly across tiers?

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div span
content: Where are the performance bottlenecks in my transactions?

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div strong span
content: OVTA-JD - Application/JVM/System Level Monitoring & Analysis

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div span
content: Is my application experiencing memory leaks?

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div span
content: Where are the source code level performance bottlenecks?

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: OVTA from HP helps you isolate application performance problems in your J2EE applications. Rather than spending the time adding those printf statements, stepping through your code, and trying to identify exactly where your performance bottleneck is occurring, you can now use a tool that can provide you with all kinds of information about your application's performance.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: OVTA captures end-to-end transaction information and tells you if your transactions are flowing smoothly across the different application tiers, including the client, the web server, the app server and the database tiers. It will show you right down to the J2EE component, the location of the performance bottlenecks in a given transaction.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: Now, we can all make mistakes in our code, especially if we're on a time crunch or are simply on a roll and hammering out code deep into the night. Once we have our code developed, how do we determine whether it contains a memory leak or a thread contention problem? Better still, how do we track the leak back to the source code and fix the issue? With the OVTA Java Diagnostics (JD) tool, we can quickly determine if our application is experiencing any memory leaks, and where any source code level performance bottlenecks are located.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: Now you can do all of this in matter of minutes. Instead of spending a half-day stepping through various aspects of your code, trying to piece together the performance puzzle and making guesses on where the performance bottleneck might be, you can use OVTA to quickly diagnose the performance problems in your application.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td h2 span
content: Demonstration: isolating performance problems with HP OVTA

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td h4 span
content: Background

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td p span
content: An application performance problem has been detected in HP OpenView Internet Services

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td h4 span
content: Demonstration

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td p span
content: Isolating the performance problem using HP OpenView Transaction Analyzer

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: Let's take a look at how we can isolate an application performance problem in our application using OVTA.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: In this particular scenario, an IT operator or the application owner is monitoring the application for availability and response time. They might be using a product such as HP OpenView Internet Service (OVIS) to monitor the application from end-to-end to determine overall availability and performance. Here, we see a screenshot of this product indicating that the response time of our application is not in an acceptable state. As the operator or support specialist does some quick root cause analysis, he finds that it is your application that isn't performing up to defined service levels. He contacts you immediately and asks you to look at a problem that is occurring with your application. He doesn't tell you much except that your application transaction response time rate is twice the accepted rate. So how are you going to solve this problem? Let's now take a look at this problem through the perspective of OVTA.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td h2 span
content: A re-cap of OVTA

tag: html body text table tbody tr td div h3 span
content: Key OVTA differentiators

tag: html body text table tbody tr td ul li span
content: No source code changes required

tag: html body text table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Data correlated end-to-end across application tiers

tag: html body text table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Very low performance impact on production systems

tag: html body text table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Integrated SLA monitoring, reporting, and alarming

tag: html body text table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Closes the loop between operations and development

tag: html body text table tbody tr td div h3 span
content: Extended application and platform support

tag: html body text table tbody tr td ul li span
content: HP-UX, Solaris, Windows, Linux, and Itanium

tag: html body text table tbody tr td ul li span
content: .NET, J2EE, and web services support

tag: html body text table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Supports WebLogic Portal, JMS and Struts

tag: html body text table tbody tr td ul li span
content: JMX metrics to monitor WebLogic Server health

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: In the demonstration, transaction data was correlated across all of the application tiers. This is particularly important when you are trying to assess the exact component causing the bottleneck, including network or database issues that are beyond your control. This can cut the diagnostic time down to just minutes so that you can quickly address the problem.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: HP also offers OVTA Java Diagnostics, a profiling tool that allows you to perform application level analysis on running J2EE applications. The tool enables operations staff and developers to work together effectively in diagnosing performance bottlenecks, helping to diagnose memory leaks, source code performance problems, and other JVM issues.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: Additionally, the impact of having OVTA monitoring and tracking the performance of your application is very low. At a high level, the product provides sufficient data to monitor the application with negligible overhead. You can also tune the amount of trace information captured when performing diagnostics. And even then, the overhead can be controlled to stay at very acceptable ranges while the problem is assessed.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: OVTA offers broad platform and application support, supporting HP-UX, Solaris, Windows, and Linux, and is capable of supporting both J2EE and .NET platforms. The product is optimized to support the WebLogic platform. Additionally, the product leverages JMX technology to monitor and assess the overall health of the WebLogic server. Metrics such as JVM memory utilization can be used to correlate the health of the server with the performance of your application.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td h2 span
content: Moving beyond performance management

tag: html body text table tbody tr td div h3 span
content: Why is designing for manageability important?

tag: html body text table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Ensures high degree of application availability

tag: html body text table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Minimizes support demands on the developer

tag: html body text table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Enables tighter linkage between business and IT

tag: html body text table tbody tr td div h3 span
content: What can you rely on for manageability?

tag: html body text table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Most J2EE platforms, including WebLogic, support JMX

tag: html body text table tbody tr td ul li span
content: HP OpenView can monitor JMX-enabled applications

tag: html body text table tbody tr td div h3 span
content: What role can you play in manageability?

tag: html body text table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Determine requirements for application manageability

tag: html body text table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Select the right management technology (Log4J, JMX)

tag: html body text table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Instrument the application, if required

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: We have just looked at a way to diagnose J2EE application performance problems using OVTA. One way to deal with these issues is to have the right sets of tools on hand to diagnose problems when they occur.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: But, what if you could design your application in such a way that it contains sufficient information to be better managed in operations? Today, operations relies on the developer because the information available to them is not sufficient to handle the problem themselves. If you can make your applications more "management aware", you can hopefully minimize the demands IT support places on you.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: Additionally, designing applications with "management in mind" has some clear benefits to your organization. With the right set of management interfaces exposed by an application, and operator can ensure a higher degree of application availability. Manageable application can also be made more flexible and adaptive in production.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: What can you do to make applications more manageable? The good news is that many application platforms today provide some amount management out-of-the-box. Almost all J2EE platforms, including WebLogic, expose management interfaces for the platform in the form of JMX MBeans. These interfaces can then leveraged by management systems such as HP OpenView.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: In some cases, platform-level management is not sufficient to effectively manage an application in production. Some amount of work might be required by the developer up-front to expose application-level management interfaces.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td h2 span
content: Application management solutions with HP OpenView and BEA

tag: html body text table tbody tr td div span
content: HP OpenView is a BEA preferred priority choice management partner

tag: html body text table tbody tr td strong span
content: HP OpenView Internet Services

tag: html body text table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Provides a view of the customer experience

tag: html body text table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Monitors end-to-end performance and availability

tag: html body text table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Supports applications deployed on the BEA platform

tag: html body text table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Monitors discrete protocols within J2EE or .NET

tag: html body text table tbody tr td strong span
content: HP OpenView Transaction Analyzer

tag: html body text table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Drill-down into applications

tag: html body text table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Root-cause analysis

tag: html body text table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Eliminate performance bottlenecks

tag: html body text table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Component-level diagnostics

tag: html body text table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Supports BEA WLS and Portal

tag: html body text table tbody tr td strong span
content: HP OpenView Operations + Smart Plugs-ins

tag: html body text table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Proactively monitor and manage IT environment

tag: html body text table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Determine service impacts through service views

tag: html body text table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Supports applications running on WLS or WLI

tag: html body text table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Extensible through custom JMX MBeans

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: Your application may be developed in isolation, but it probably won't run in isolation. There are dependencies on the application server, the database, and other IT infrastructure components. This larger "management ecosystem" requires the right level of manageability at all layers, and you play an important role here.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: The HP OpenView Application Management Solution allows an application owner to comprehensively monitor their business-critical application environment. OVTA provides the insight into the application itself by drilling down to the component or method level, enabling you to quickly find the source of performance bottlenecks. OpenView Internet Services provides a view of the customer experience by monitoring the end-to-end performance and availability of your applications. Additionally, HP offers a set of Rapid Implementation Services which can help you rapidly install and configure OVIS and OVTA in as little as 5 days. HP OpenView Operations provides the ability to map and proactively monitor the underlying infrastructure that supports applications deployed on WebLogic Server or WebLogic Integration.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: Obviously, HP can't do this alone. BEA and HP have teamed up to provide you with management solutions that ensure a high degree of stability, efficiency, and agility for the WebLogic platform. HP OpenView is already supporting WLS, WLI, and WLP to varying degrees. As a BEA preferred and priority management partner, HP is committed to further enhancing these management solutions with more robust and unique management capabilities moving forward.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td h2 span
content: Call to action

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: There are some important next steps you can take to learn more about HP's application management solutions. You can download an evaluation copy of OVTA at the HP Management Software URL listed on this page. It is very easy to install and configure to run against your own applications.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: For those of you that are considering application manageability through JMX, you are highly encouraged to visit our HP Developer Resource Central site. This site provides you with a variety of white papers, code samples, and developer tutorials on JMX. One of the tutorials shows how a BEA WebLogic sample application can be instrumented using JMX. Once you're done with this tutorial, you will have the foundation to be able to instrument your own existing applications.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: To learn more about HP OpenView and BEA application management solutions, visit the OpenView/BEA web site. You will find that together, BEA and HP OpenView offer you more control and agility, resulting in a greater competitive edge. And finally, don't forget to stop by our booth and take a closer look at OVTA and other HP OpenView management solutions.
